awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: High-mobility amorphous-iodide-based channel materials for p-type thin-film transistors and complementary TFT circuitry
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description:  Over the past decade, displays in electronic devices like laptops have been revolutionized in part by using transparent conducting amorphous oxides due to their processing versatility and higher carrier mobility combined with low-temperature, large-area deposition conditions. A team of investigators from Brown University and Technion (Israel) is investigating a new class of materials, amorphous metal iodides like CuSnI and CuPbI, that would add to the arsenal of transparent conducting materials for use in displays and other transparent circuit technologies. Compared to other amorphous materials, the amorphous metal iodides feature a different physical mechanism: under an applied voltage, the currents are carried by positively charged holes. This offers new low-power dissipation circuit possibilities, as long as the materials properties of these metal iodides, including impurity content, phase, and temperature behavior can be tuned using composition and processing parameters. The research program covers a number of topics, ranging from fundamental experimental materials science of material deposition and characterization to theoretical modeling of phase transformation and impurity incorporation to prototype transistor device fabrication, brings together transparent electronic material and device expertise at Brown University with cutting-edge materials characterization and modeling at the Technion. The research project has an educational impact in and out of the classroom, including graduate student support, Brown-Technion graduate student interaction and exchange visits, as well as outreach to underprivileged middle-school students in the Providence area.

Technical description:  Two Brown experimentalists with complementary expertise in amorphous electronic materials and device physics, in collaboration with a Technion team experienced in atomic/nano/micro characterization and physical modeling, are focusing on the need for a high-mobility wide-bandgap low-temperature p-type material for thin film transistors (TFTs). The PIs have identified amorphous iodide-based materials as the most promising: they have a wide bandgap (3 eV), high hole mobility (up to 40 cm2/V.s), native vacancy doping, and are compatible with arbitrary substrates. They are also compatible with low-temperature-deposited amorphous n-type zinc oxide-based materials, opening the way for complementary TFT circuitry. The Brown PIs are leveraging their recent demonstration of high-performance indium-zinc-oxide materials by reconfiguring an oxide sputtering tool for in-situ iodide deposition. The Brown team is developing and optimizing the synthesis of a-Cu1-xMxI thin films (M = Sn, Pb, In, and others), studying the doping mechanism via Brouwer analysis, investigating phase stability, and fabricating prototype TFT demonstrator circuits. The experimental work is complemented by the detailed materials characterization and physical modeling performed by the Technion team, that has extensive experience in nanoscale amorphous and crystalline films. The final experimental goal is to develop the deposition of both n- and p-type transparent conducting materials in the same sputter-deposition process at low temperature on arbitrary substrates. The project provides training opportunities to the participating graduate and undergraduate students in cross-cutting electronic materials and devices fields, to the Brown-Technion visitor and student exchanges, as well as to the local underprivileged middle-school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Transparent amorphous oxide-based n-type thin films are now widely used as the channel material in the thin film transistors (TFT) that control individual pixels in flat panel display technologies.   An equivalent p-type channel material that is transparent and compatible with existing processes (including large area sputter deposition at low temperatures) is not yet available but would enable energy-saving CMOS-like circuit design.  The Cu-based iodides are technologically attractive because they can be deposited at low temperatures on arbitrary substrates, while providing a wide bandgap (EG ~ 3 eV), high hole mobility (potentially in the 10–40 cm2/V.s range), and native vacancy doping.  These materials are compatible with low-temperature-deposited amorphous n-type indium zinc oxide-based TFTs used in modern displays, opening the way for truly complementary TFT circuitry.  In this work we have developed a greater technical and fundamental understanding of the challenges that have hindered previous attempts to implement p-type CuI.  In this work we have developed processes for the electronic and morphological stabilization of sputter deposited CuI and we have successfully fabricated sputter-deposited backgated p-type CuI depletion-mode TFTs with a field-effect mobility ~ 1.5–2 cm2 V-1s-1 and Ion/Ioff of up to 250, controlled by relatively low gate voltages VG < 5 V.  These results set the stage for the further development of p-type CuI based TFT devices.

 

Intellectual merit: In this project, working in collaboration with our Technion partners funded in parallel by BSF, we have examined Cu(M)I (where M= Sn, Bi, Pb) thin film growth via sputter deposition and, through microstructural and electronic characterization of as-deposited and annealed materials along with detailed modelling, we have established insights into the microstructural, morphological and carrier transport properties of this material.  We have established protocols (dielectric layers, diffusion barriers, and device fabrication processes) for protecting CuI from solvents commonly used during conventional device processing and for stabilizing CuI grain growth, surface roughness, and transport (carrier density) in CuI.   We have used these approaches to produce, for the first time, a bottom-gated p-type CuI-based depletion-mode TFT with field effect mobility of ~ 1.5–2 cm2 V-1s-1 and Ion/Ioff of up to 250.  A schematic of the device and a full microstructural characterization of the fabricated device in cross-section is shown in FIG. 1 while the output characteristics are shown in FIG. 2 (a and b).  A model of the device was built in an industrial TCAD simulator which reproduces the measured characteristics (FIG. 2c) and allows for an estimation of interface state densities and channel doping. Further, we have performed controlled atmosphere in situ annealing measurements of the resistivity of CuI in alternating oxidizing and reducing ambient atmospheres.  These measurements, confirm that oxygen plays a role as a p-type acceptor defect in these materials and provide a framework for controlling carrier density in the channel region of CuI-based TFT’s.   

 

Broader impact: The main research thrust sponsored by this award has produced CuI TFTs with competitive electrical characteristics.  The research has provided training support to two PhD students, one of whom will graduate in the coming two years.  It provided for an ongoing scientific collaboration on CuI electronics modeling with a Technion theorist (A. Katsman).  Several undergraduates (4) have participated in this research and two have produced honors and/or capstone design theses based their work on this project.   Two of these undergraduates are co-authors on a recently submitted paper: Natalia Thomas, who is now employed as an engineer by St Gobain, and Kyumin Kim, who has moved on to a PhD program at Univ. of Toronto. 

This program has also led to significant outreach to the community.   Throughout the NSF award, co-PI Zaslavsky (a fanatical squash player) volunteered 3 hours per week of mostly mathematics tutoring, with occasional forays into physics or science at the Providence SquashBusters program.  The idea of SquashBusters is to introduce the sport to underprivileged urban youth and combine athletic training and discipline with regular academic tutoring to prepare the students for college-level work. The Providence SquashBusters program took in a cohort of underprivileged middle school students from the urban DelSesto Middle School in Providence and followed them through their high-school years. The end of this NSF award coincided with the graduation of the first Providence SquashBusters high-school class of 11 students.  All 11 are members of under-represented groups and all 11 are continuing to higher education, at either four-year or two-year institutions, with destinations as follows: Connecticut College (1), Providence College (3), Rhode Island College (3), Community College of RI (4).  Furthermore, ten out 11 students will be first in their families to attend college and all will be attending without any student loan debt.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2024
Modified by: David C Paine

por.por_txt_cntn:
Transparent amorphous oxide-based n-type thin films are now widely used as the channel material in the thin film transistors (TFT) that control individual pixels in flat panel display technologies. An equivalent p-type channel material that is transparent and compatible with existing processes (including large area sputter deposition at low temperatures) is not yet available but would enable energy-saving CMOS-like circuit design. The Cu-based iodides are technologically attractive because they can be deposited at low temperatures on arbitrary substrates, while providing a wide bandgap (EG ~ 3 eV), high hole mobility (potentially in the 1040 cm2/V.s range), and native vacancy doping. These materials are compatible with low-temperature-deposited amorphous n-type indium zinc oxide-based TFTs used in modern displays, opening the way for truly complementary TFT circuitry. In this work we have developed a greater technical and fundamental understanding of the challenges that have hindered previous attempts to implement p-type CuI. In this work we have developed processes for the electronic and morphological stabilization of sputter deposited CuI and we have successfully fabricated sputter-deposited backgated p-type CuI depletion-mode TFTs with a field-effect mobility ~ 1.52 cm2 V-1s-1 and Ion/Ioff of up to 250, controlled by relatively low gate voltages VG p-type CuI based TFT devices.





Intellectual merit: In this project, working in collaboration with our Technion partners funded in parallel by BSF, we have examined Cu(M)I (where M= Sn, Bi, Pb) thin film growth via sputter deposition and, through microstructural and electronic characterization of as-deposited and annealed materials along with detailed modelling, we have established insights into the microstructural, morphological and carrier transport properties of this material. We have established protocols (dielectric layers, diffusion barriers, and device fabrication processes) for protecting CuI from solvents commonly used during conventional device processing and for stabilizing CuI grain growth, surface roughness, and transport (carrier density) in CuI. We have used these approaches to produce, for the first time, a bottom-gated p-type CuI-based depletion-mode TFT with field effect mobility of ~ 1.52 cm2 V-1s-1 and Ion/Ioff of up to 250. A schematic of the device and a full microstructural characterization of the fabricated device in cross-section is shown in FIG. 1 while the output characteristics are shown in FIG. 2 (a and b). A model of the device was built in an industrial TCAD simulator which reproduces the measured characteristics (FIG. 2c) and allows for an estimation of interface state densities and channel doping. Further, we have performed controlled atmosphere in situ annealing measurements of the resistivity of CuI in alternating oxidizing and reducing ambient atmospheres. These measurements, confirm that oxygen plays a role as a p-type acceptor defect in these materials and provide a framework for controlling carrier density in the channel region of CuI-based TFTs.





Broader impact: The main research thrust sponsored by this award has produced CuI TFTs with competitive electrical characteristics. The research has provided training support to two PhD students, one of whom will graduate in the coming two years. It provided for an ongoing scientific collaboration on CuI electronics modeling with a Technion theorist (A. Katsman). Several undergraduates (4) have participated in this research and two have produced honors and/or capstone design theses based their work on this project. Two of these undergraduates are co-authors on a recently submitted paper: Natalia Thomas, who is now employed as an engineer by St Gobain, and Kyumin Kim, who has moved on to a PhD program at Univ. of Toronto.


This program has also led to significant outreach to the community. Throughout the NSF award, co-PI Zaslavsky (a fanatical squash player) volunteered 3 hours per week of mostly mathematics tutoring, with occasional forays into physics or science at the Providence SquashBusters program. The idea of SquashBusters is to introduce the sport to underprivileged urban youth and combine athletic training and discipline with regular academic tutoring to prepare the students for college-level work. The Providence SquashBusters program took in a cohort of underprivileged middle school students from the urban DelSesto Middle School in Providence and followed them through their high-school years. The end of this NSF award coincided with the graduation of the first Providence SquashBusters high-school class of 11 students. All 11 are members of under-represented groups and all 11 are continuing to higher education, at either four-year or two-year institutions, with destinations as follows: Connecticut College (1), Providence College (3), Rhode Island College (3), Community College of RI (4). Furthermore, ten out 11 students will be first in their families to attend college and all will be attending without any student loan debt.
